questions.text: A person on total parenteral nutrition was given 62.5 g of protein. Calculate the amount of nitrogen present in this amount of protein:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10 g Approximately, Nitrogen contributes to 16% of proteins 100 gm of protein contains 16 gm of nitrogen. So, 62.5 gm of protein will contain, 62.5 X 16/100 gm of nitrogen, i.e. 10 gm of nitrogen. Extra Edge: The formula for calculating the nitrogen balance of patients: Nitrogen balance = Nitrogen intake – Nitrogen loss = (Protein intake x 0.16) – (24-hour urinary urea nitrogen + 4) Why to add 4? 4 gm of nitrogen is lost through other sources.

questions.text: Proteins are polypeptides formed by joining together of series of amino acids through peptide bonds. A peptide bond is formed between:

options.label: A
options.text: Carboxyl group on one amino acid and the R-group of adjacent amino acid

options.label: B
options.text: Carboxyl group on both amino acids

options.label: C
options.text: The amino group on one amino acid and the carboxyl group of the adjacent amino acid

options.label: D
options.text: The amino group of both amino acids

questions.correct_answer: C. The amino group on one amino acid and the carboxyl group of the adjacent amino acid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The amino group on one amino acid and the carboxyl group of the adjacent amino acid A peptide bond is a special type of amide bond between the α-carboxyl group of one amino acid and the α-amino group of the adjacent amino acid.

Extraedge:

Structure Bonds Primary structure Covalent/amide/peptide bond Secondary structure Hydrogen bonds Tertiary structure Disulphide, Hydrogen, Hydrophobic and Ionic bond Quaternary structure Hydrogen, hydrophobic, and ionic bond

questions.text: In the following diagram, what are incorrect statements about the protein structure:

options.label: A
options.text: Various proteins exist as single polypeptide chains. These are termed monomeric proteins

options.label: B
options.text: Others exist as two or more than two polypeptide chains that can be structurally similar or dissimilar. This type of arrangement of the polypeptide subunits is termed a quaternary structure of the protein.

options.label: C
options.text: The subunit polypeptide chains are bonded by non-covalent forces like hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and hydrophobic interactions

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Various proteins exist as single polypeptide chains. These are termed as monomeric proteins others exist as two or more than two polypeptide chains that can be structurally similar of Dissimilar. This type of arrangement of the polypeptide subunits is termed as quaternary structure of the protein. The subunit polypeptide chains are bonded by non-covalent forces like hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and hydrophobic interactions Option A: Correct. Monomeric proteins consist of a single polypeptide chain. Option B: Correct. Proteins with more than one polypeptide chain exhibit quaternary structure. Option C: Correct. The subunits in a quaternary structure are held together by non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and hydrophobic interactions. Option D: This implies that none of the statements are incorrect, which aligns with our analysis. Since all statements are factually correct, the provided answer (“None of the above are incorrect”) as per my knowledge is correct

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Monomeric proteins are single polypeptide chains. Various proteins exist as single polypeptide chains. These are termed monomeric proteins Option: B. Others exist as two or more than two polypeptide chains that can be structurally similar or dissimilar. This type of arrangement of the polypeptide subunits is termed a quaternary structure of the protein. Option: C. The subunit polypeptide chains are bonded by non-covalent forces like hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and hydrophobic interactions

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was admitted to the ER with a large amount of blood and protein in his urine. He also has misshaped lenses (anterior lenticonus) and sensorineural hearing loss in his teenage years. The physician suspected it to be a case of Alport syndrome and ordered a genetic test. The tests would most likely show a defect in which of the proteins?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Collagen In Alport syndrome, there is a defect in type IV collagen that changes the composition of the basement membrane kidney glomeruli. Due to the absence of a functional basement membrane, the kidneys are unable to properly filter waste products from the blood and both proteins and blood can enter the urine. Type IV collagen is also found in the inner ear so it is important for hearing and for the eye. A mutation in α1-antitrypsin will lead to emphysema, mutations in fibrillin lead to Marfan syndrome, and mutations in the β-myosin heavy chain can lead to FHC (Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)

questions.text: Proteins present in humans almost exclusively contain right-handed helices. However, there is a rarity of functional proteins with left-handed helix. Which of the following amino acids shows a tendency to form a left-handed helix?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycine All the amino acids in human proteins are L-amino acids which have the propensity to form right-handed helix. Glycine does not have a chiral carbon. So, there is no D or L-form for glycine. Because of this flexibility, Glycine can form a left-handed helix like collagen helix. (Note: Collagen helix is NOT an alpha helix).

questions.text: All of the following are true about the stationary phase used in high-pressure liquid chromatography, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Provides low resolution The stationary phase in HPLC is made up of fine silicone particles → option A is correct As there are a lot of fine particles, the surface area is increased, and resistance to the mobile phase is increased. That is why we apply high-pressure → option B and C are correct As the surface area is high, the chance interaction between stationary and mobile phase is high → good separation is achieved, i.e. resolution is high, not low → option D is wrong

questions.text: Column chromatography using phenyl Sepharose beads separates proteins based on the:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrophobicity Hydrophobic interaction chromatography separates proteins on basis of their tendency to attach with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups (eg. phenyl Sepharose). In this chromatography, hydrophobic groups such as octyl, butyl, or phenyl are attached to the stationary column. Proteins that are passing through the column having hydrophobic amino acid side chains on their surfaces interact with and bind to the hydrophobic groups on the column.

questions.text: The ability of amino acids/proteins to behave like zwitterions forms the basis for separating them using the following technique:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isoelectric focusing Isoelectric focusing is based on the isoelectric pH (pH at which a molecule carries no net charge). pH gradients created in the gel using polyampholytes. As there is no net charge, molecule stops moving during electrophoresis if they encounter their pI.

questions.text: Glutathione is the major intracellular reducing substance/anti-oxidant with the -SH group of glutathione providing its antioxidant function. Glutathione is a:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tripeptide Glutathione is -glutamyl cysteinyl glycine, i.e. glutathione is a tripeptide made up of 3 aminoacyl residues – Glutamate, Cysteine, Glycine Gluta - Glutamate Thi- Sulfur containing (Cysteine) One- Glycine (1 C amino acid) Glutathione is the major intracellular reducing substance/anti-oxidant SH group of glutathione is responsible for its antioxidant function.

questions.text: Keratin protein present in the hair, nails, and outer layer of skin is almost completely composed of alpha-helices (secondary structure). Which amino acid out of the following is responsible for its strength and rigidity?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cysteine In keratin, two alpha-helices are wound around one another to form a superhelix Strength and rigidity in keratin is due to Cysteine because of its ability to form disulf ide bonds . Two molecules of Cysteine join together to form Cystine, which has a disulfide bond (see fig) The number of disulf ide bonds is directly proportional to the rigidity of keratin i.e. more the disulfide bonds, the harder the keratin.

questions.text: The structure of a protein is highly correlated to its function hence structure determination can reveal the function of a newly discovered protein. Which technique is most widely used to study the structure of protein:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

X-ray crystallography In the question, they have not mentioned the nature of structure such as 1 o , 2 o, or 3 o, , etc. In this case, consider tertiary structure (3D structure). So, mark X-ray crystallography (X-ray crystallography can detect the 3-D structure of any macromolecule). Additional information on this topic: Mass spectrometry : The b est technique to determine → primary structure of proteins This technique is Qualitative as well as Quantitative Can detect post-translational modifications (like hydroxylation) or covalent modifications of enzymes (like phosphorylation and dephosphorylation) Can detect the exact molecular weight of the protein (as the name says - MASS).

questions.text: Failure of protein to fold into its native structure generally produces inactive proteins or protein with modified or toxic functionality resulting in degenerative diseases. Which of the following is NOT a protein misfolding disorder:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tuberculosis Protein misfolding diseases are also known as proteopathies or protein conformational disorders or disorders of proteostasis. Protein conformational disorders Major aggregating protein Alzheimer's disease Amyloid β peptide (Aβ);Tau protein Prion diseases Prion protein Parkinson's disease and other synucleinopathies α-Synuclein Tauopathies Microtubule-associated protein tau (Tau protein) Huntington's disease and other poly Q diseases Proteins with tandem glutamine expansions Alexander disease Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) Familial amyloidotic neuropathy, Senile systemic amyloidosis Transthyretin Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis Surfactant proteins Cystic Fibrosis cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein Sickle cell disease Hemoglobin

questions.text: A patient on physical examination showed tall and thin body habitus, loose joints, and arachnodactyly (spider fingers). Ophthalmologic examination reveals lens dislocation. The patient is most likely to have a mutation in the genes for the synthesis of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycoprotein The Diagnosis is Marfan Syndrome. It is an AD disease caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15 , which encodes Fibrillin-1 . Fibrillin-1 is a Glycoprotein (Structural component of microfibrils) Helps in the deposition of elastin The mutation will adversely affect bones, heart, and eyes and elastin will also be affected. C/F Tall stature Long limbs Lens dislocation Arachnodactyly The media of large arteries is weak. (defective elastin) Death occurs due to rupture of the dilated aorta

questions.text: The tensile strength of collagen fibers is provided by its triple helical structure. Which amino acid is most essential for allowing triple-helix formation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycine The folding of collagen as a triple helix is because of the presence of Glycine. Collagen is made up of 3 alpha chains (not alpha-helix). These 3 chains together make a superhelix --> Tropocollagen (a rope-like triple-helix) Each turn of the helix contains three amino acid residues with every third amino acid in close contact with the other two strands in the center of the structure. Only glycine, which lacks a side chain, can fit in this restricted space where three chains of helix come together.

questions.text: 28 different types of collagen have been identified, described, and classified into several groups according to their structure. Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen in humans and is present in all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cartilage Type Tissue I Skin, bone, cornea, aponeurosis II Cartilage (hyaline, elastic) III Blood vessels, healing/granulation tissue, lymphoid organ (Sleep, Liver, Lymph Node) IV Basement membrane

questions.text: Certain amino acids are not part of the primary structure of proteins but are modified after translation. Such a modified amino acid that is present abundantly in bone is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydroxyproline The m ost abundant protein in bones is collagen . Collagen is formed from Glycine Proline Lysine Proline and lysine are hydroxylated to make OH-proline and OH-lysine. So the most abundant modified amino acid in bone is hydroxyproline.

Extraedge:

OH-proline cause extensive hydrogen bonding and hence collagen provide strength to the bones.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is suffering from a neurodegenerative disease. Autopsies showed the presence of amyloid proteins in various parts of the brain. The most likely diagnosis of this patient is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alzheimer disease PROTEIN MISFOLDING AND DISEASES- Amyloidosis - Amyloids is used to refer to the altered proteins (with beta-sheets) that accumulate in the body, particularly in the nervous system Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder Accumulation of beta- amyloid . Other examples of amyloidosis: table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Type Protein Implicated Primary Principally light chains of immunoglobulins Secondary Serum amyloid (A (SAA) Familial Transthyretin; others:- apolipoprotein A-1, Cystatin C, fibrinogen, gelsolin, Lysozyme Alzheimer's disease Amyloid β peptide Dialysis - related β 2 - microglobulin Prion disease – Etiology: Proteinaceous infectious agents No change in 1º structures and posttranslation modification Change in 3D structures ( major change is the replacement of alpha helix by beta sheets ) Can act as a template to convert non-infectious proteins (with cl-helices) to infectious forms Example - Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) and Creutzfeldt Jakob disease in humans. Scrapie disease - sheep Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (popularly known as mad cow disease) in cattle

questions.text: The correct folding of newly synthesized proteins to their native and functional form is essential for their function. Which of the following groups of proteins assist in the proper folding of other proteins?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chaperones Chaperons are proteins that are involved in the folding of the protein Protein Synthesis occurs in Endoplasmic Reticulum ( ER ), Ribosomes attached to ER are RER Chaperons are present in RER so that during the translation process, side-by-side folding can also occur so that the result of translation is a fully folded polypeptide chain
